III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central registry
Description (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and suitable
and able to meet the needs of children and families served by the
agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 5/20/25 Complainant reported to DHHS that Foster Care
Worker attempted to touch Parent’s phone in an assertive manner
to stop Parent from recording. Foster Care Worker then canceled
parenting time to be “cruel and unusual” toward Parent. This
occurred in May 2025.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed via video call on
5/29/25. FCS reported they did not attend the parenting time visit.
However, they heard a voice recording of the visit, as Parent
posted it on Facebook. In the recording it can be heard that
Parent questions Foster Care Worker about the case. Foster Care
Worker redirected Parent several times to focus on visiting with
her children and stated that the case could be discussed later.
Parent became verbally aggressive, and Foster Care Worker
indicated the visit would end if that continued. Parent continued to
be verbally aggressive and was not visiting with the children.
Therefore, the visit ended. Foster Care Worker told FCS that
during the visit she went to pick up her papers, which were near
Parent’s phone. Parent became escalated, even though Foster
Care Worker was not touching the phone.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via video call on
5/29/25. FCW stated she recalled the parenting visit that ended
early on 5/15/25. Prior to the visit, Parent sent the worker
numerous texts. Including a 99-page email. The worker had not
reviewed all of the material prior to arriving at the visit. When
Parent arrived, she asked FCW if she had read everything. FCW
worker stated she had not, and this was visit time so Parent
should be focusing on that. Parent continued arguing with FCW
and Relative Caregiver 1. Due to her being verbally aggressive
(swearing and threatening) and refusing to focus on visiting with
the children, the visit was cancelled. Parent initially refused to
leave but eventually did. This was the only visit canceled in person
by FCW. Another visit was canceled on 5/30/25 as Parent refused
to confirm the visit time with the agency.
FCW explained when Parent initially arrived at the visit, she put
her belongings on top of the papers that FCW was going over with
2

Relative Caregiver 1. Later, when FCW picked up her papers,
she may have moved Parent’s phone. Although she could not
recall if it was picked up or moved over. Foster Care Worker
denied attempting to turn the phone off, or aggressively grabbing
the phone. Parent was recording the conversation on her phone,
as she did with most conversations. Parent later posted the
conversation on Facebook.
Relative Caregiver 1 was interviewed by phone on 6/26/25.
Relative Caregiver 1 stated they recalled the 5/15/25 parenting
time at the home. Parent arrived for the visit, walked by the kids
and went directly to FCW. Parent asked FCW about paperwork
and began yelling. FCW redirected Parent, stating she was there
to visit with her children and needed to do that. Parent continued
yelling. FCW redirected again and stated the visit would be
canceled if she was not going to focus on her children. Parent
continued to be confrontational and yell. FCW was calm and
ended the visit. Parent continued to yell. Relative Caregiver 1
instructed Parent to leave their home. Parent began yelling and
swearing at Relative Caregiver 1. When asked if FCW touched
Parent’s phone, Relative Caregiver 1 stated that did not happen.
Parent put her phone down on top of FCWs papers. When worker
picked up her papers, Parent began yelling that FCW touched her
phone, but that did not happen. Relative Caregiver 1 stated Parent
made several allegations against everyone involved in the case,
resulting in some restraining orders and the case transferring to
different workers and agencies. Relative Caregiver 1 added
Parent has cancelled the last three parenting visits.
Documents reviewed:
• Foster Care case record
o Kids placed with Relative Caregivers on 4/28/25
o Case transferred to agency from DHHS on 4/28/25
o Case returned to DHHS on 5/27/25
• Case Contacts
o 5/15/25 Parenting Time “Parent arrived for her
scheduled parenting time. She began the session by
asking the FCW if she saw her text. The FCW
informed Parent that she did see the set of texts, but
she was in the process of driving. Parent informed
that she was recoding and slammed a stack of
papers onto the table on top of the FCW folder and
paperwork. Parent remained confrontational and
agitated. The FCW reminded her that she was there
to visit with her children and that this could be
discussed later. Parent continued to be aggressive
3

and agitated. The FCW ended the visit and asked
Parent to leave. Parent continued and the caregivers
also asked her to leave their home. Parent left after
sating allegations of being a pervert and cursing at
the caregivers and FCW. She remained sitting
outside the home for 10-15 minutes. The caregivers
requested that the visits be moved and stated that
Parent was no longer welcome in their home. The
caregivers were visibly shaken up. The FCW stayed
for an additional 20-30 minutes to assure the
children and caregivers were ok. The children
witnessed this interaction, but did not react to them.”
Audio review:
• An audio recording of the 5/15/25 visit was reviewed. The
recording was consistent with FCW’s interview and case
contact notes.
• Another audio recording from 5/15/25 was reviewed. Parent
and an unknown person were on the recording. Parent
stated FCW tried to turn her phone off, because Parent was
documenting the visit. Parent was upset that when she told
FCW she was recording, FCW responded, “I know you are.
You always are”. Unknown person responded that the
worker cannot decide who ends cases and who does not,
and that a supervisor was aware.
Analysis No violation was found. Based on interviews and review of the
audio recording, there was no indication Foster Care Worker
grabbed Parent’s phone. In addition, the audio recording and
Relative Caregiver 1’s account of the incident corroborated Foster
Care Worker’s report that the visit was ended early due to Parent
being verbally aggressive and not visiting with the children.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12320 Supervision
Section (1) An agency shall ensure an appropriate level of care and
Description supervision for the foster child at all times consistent with a child's
age, level of functioning, and treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 5/20/25 Complainant reported that the agency approved
sleeping arrangements where a one-year-old child could sleep on
a bed that was “high off the ground, with no fall protection”.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed via video call on
5/29/25. FCS reported the children’s beds were approved by
DHHS, before the agency accepted the case. At the time the case
4

was transferred on 4/28/25, the one-year-old child was sleeping
on a twin mattress on the floor. This was due to a delivery delay in
the beds ordered by DHHS. The toddler bed was delivered on
4/30/25. FCS was not aware of any other sleeping arrangements.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via video call on
5/29/25. FCW reported the placement and sleeping arrangements
were approved by DHHS, prior to this agency receiving the case.
When FCW first visited the home, there was a set of bunk beds
and two twin beds. The intention was for the one-year-old to sleep
on the bottom bunk bed. However, only the bunk and one twin
were present. FCW contacted DHHS to let them know. Relative
Caregiver 1 reported that one-year-old was sleeping on a mattress
on the floor while they waited for the toddler bed. FCW submitted
a request for a toddler bed. The bed was purchased and delivered
to the caregiver’s home. The case then transferred back to DHHS
on 5/27/25. FCW reported she was not aware of the child sleeping
in an unsafe bed at any time.
Relative Caregiver 1 was interviewed by phone on 6/26/25.
Relative Caregiver 1 reported they had a set of twin bunk beds
with the nine-year-old sleeping on the top bunk and four-year-old
on the bottom bunk. A twin bed was used for the three-year-old,
and a toddler bed for the one-year-old. Relative Caregiver 1 stated
they received the bunk beds and a twin bed first, then the toddler
bed. The one-year-old never slept on the bunk bed or in any other
unsafe situations.
DHHS Worker was contacted via email on 6/26/25 regarding the
children’s initial placement with Relative Caregiver 1. DHHS
Worker authored the Relative Approval Placement & Safety
Screen (DHHS 5770) dated 4/29/25 and Relative Placement
Home Study (DHHS 3130A) on 5/22/25. The reports indicated
there were three twin beds and a toddler bed in the home. DHHS
Worker stated they never observed any children to be in unsafe
sleeping arrangements. DHHS Worker stated she did not have
any concerns, or discussion with Relative Caregiver 1 related to
unsafe sleeping arrangements.
Documents reviewed:
• DHHS 5770 Relative Approval & Placement Safety Screen
completed by DHHS on 4/30/25. “The home is found to be
safe and appropriate for placement”.
• DHHS 3130A completed by DHHS on 5/22/25. Report
documented three twin size beds and a toddler bed.
5

Analysis No violation was found. Based on interviews and documentation
of the home at the time of placement approval by DHHS, there
was no indication that a one-year-old child was sleeping in a bed
high off the ground. In addition, there was no indication FCS or
FCW approved an unsafe sleeping arrangement.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
Section (4) An agency shall consider all the following factors in selecting
Description an appropriate placement for a child:
(d) Expressed preferences of the child, and the child's parent or
parents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The children are placed in the home of a sexual abuser, against
parent wishes.
Investigation On 5/20/25 Complainant reported that Parent’s children are not
safe and are being kept in the home of a “sexual abuser”. In a
follow up-email on 5/20/25 Complainant stated the home was
unsafe as Parent was sexually abused and kidnapped while living
there. Complainant reported other concerns about the caregivers
which were also reported to MDHHS and not related to this
agency.
Interviews:
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed via video call on
5/29/25. FCS reported that criminal clearances were completed by
DHHS, and the placement was approved before the case
transferred to this agency on 4/28/25. Per documents received by
the agency, Relative Caregiver 1 disclosed that her ex-boyfriend
was a sex offender. However, he was incarcerated and did not
have contact with the family. FCS was not aware of any sex
offenders living in the home.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via video call on
5/29/25. DHHS completed clearances and approved placement
with Relative Caregiver 1, prior to the case transferring to this
agency. FCW stated that she believed Parent was referring to
Relative Caregiver 1’s ex-boyfriend, who was incarcerated for
sexual assault in 2010. The ex-boyfriend did not live in the home,
as he was incarcerated, and did not have any contact with the
children. FCW reported she did not have any concerns regarding
Relative Caregiver 1 or Relative Caregiver 2. FCW was not aware
of any sex offenders living in the home, as the two Relative
Caregiver’s were the only people in the home, aside from the
children.
6

DHHS Worker was contacted via email on 6/26/25 regarding the
children’s initial placement with Relative Caregiver 1. DHHS
worker reported clearances were completed for Relative Caregiver
1 and Relative Caregiver 2 on 4/29/25, with no findings noted.
DHHS Worker stated she did not have any concerns.
Relative Caregiver 1 was interviewed by phone on 6/26/25.
Relative Caregiver 1 reported no one in the home had sexually
abused anyone. Relative Caregiver 1 confirmed that clearances
were completed by DHHS when the children were placed in the
home.
Documents reviewed:
• DHHS 5770 Relative Approval & Placement Safety Screen
completed by DHHS on 4/28/25. Criminal clearances
(Central Registry, MPSOR and ICHAT) were completed
without any findings on 4/28/25. “The home is found to be
safe and appropriate for placement”.
Audio recording reviewed
Parent provided an audio recording with a law enforcement officer,
in which Parent reported being concerned about her children. Law
Enforcement responded they did seven home checks in May
2025, due to Parent requesting welfare checks. Law Enforcement
did not have any concerns when they visited the children. Nor
were there any investigations or charges pending in relation to her
concerns.
Analysis No violation was found. Based on interviews and case
documentation, clearances were completed for Relative Caregiver
1 and Relative Caregiver 2. Neither caregiver had a history of
criminal sexual conduct. Nor were there any open investigations
or concerns identified by DHHS at the time of placement, or by
Foster Care Worker during the time she was involved with the
case.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
Section (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must, include all
Description the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated: (i) A comprehensive
medical examination, including a behavioral/mental health and
trauma screening, within 30 calendar days from the date the child
entered into an out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of
the last physical examination.
7

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster Care Worker did not allow the parent to schedule a needed
medical appointment for the children.
Investigation On 5/20/25 Complainant reported that the children’s health was
being neglected. Parent was not allowed to schedule health
appointments at a facility for genetic testing.
Interviews:
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed via video call on
5/29/25. FCS reported Parent wanted the children to see
specialists that were not already scheduled. Parent would not
disclose why these specialist appointments were needed. FCS
stated the children were scheduled for routine medical
appointments, which needed to occur prior to referral for any
specialist appointments. The routine medicals were completed on
5/23/25, at which time there were referrals made for dermatology
and genetic testing. FCS stated Parent indicated one child had a
heart murmur, which was cleared five years ago, but parent did
not trust the doctor and wanted a second opinion. FCS stated
documents were in MiSACWIS to confirm this information.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via video call on
5/29/25. FCW reported on 5/12/25 Parent sent a request with
attachments that totaled 99 pages regarding things she wanted
the worker to do. This document included scheduling
appointments with specialists for various things. On 5/14/25 FCW
explained to Parent that these items would be discussed with the
primary doctor at the well-child visit. FCW stated it was necessary
for the primary doctor to make referrals, before appointments
could be scheduled. At the well-child visit on 5/23/25 the primary
doctor made referrals to dermatology, and genetic testing as
Parent requested. A follow-up was scheduled to address Parent’s
other concerns and determine if any other referrals were needed.
The doctor did not have any concerns about the children’s health,
other than eczema.
Relative Caregiver 1 was interviewed by phone on 6/26/25.
Relative Caregiver 1 reported all four children had a check up with
their doctor in May. Relative Caregiver 1 did not have any medical
concerns about the youth, but stated Parent requested specialist
appointments, which had been scheduled.
Documents reviewed:
8

Well-child exams dated 5/23/25 for Youth A, Youth B, Youth C
and Youth D. Parent attended visit and provided input to doctor.
Referrals included:
• Youth A- allergy specialist and psychiatrist for ADHD
evaluation.
• Youth B- genetic testing due to concerns of
immunization response.
• Youth C- genetic testing due to concerns about family
history.
• Youth D- allergy and immunology, and pediatric dental
referral.
Analysis No violation was found. Based on interviews and documentation
from the case file, the children had a well-child exam completed
within the required timeframe. The specialist referrals could not be
made at the time of Parent’s request on 5/14/25, as an
appointment to establish the children as patients was needed first.
At the visit on 5/23/25, the primary care doctor made referrals as
requested.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
